channel.title: Arch Linux Is Win
channel.description: I just installed and fully set up Arch Linux. It's totally awesome. It's very fast and easy to use once you set it up. I'm running fluxbox on it. For those of you who run ArchLinux, what desktop environment/window managers are you running?

item.title: Arch Linux Is Win
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

I like KDE better, but it is all personal preference, and you can change that later if you want. For a beginner I would start with kubuntu. If you want to know if something works on WINE your best bet is http://appdb.winehq.org/

Read full topic

item.title: Arch Linux Is Win
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

different desktop environments, ubuntu uses gnome, kubuntu uses KDE, and xubuntu uses that other one that starts with x,

other then that, identical

[quote=“bowserjr2, post:25, topic:191939”][quote author=Silver Lining link=topic=255620.msg2149315#msg2149315 date=1206967055]
Uh, I don’t run Arch at the moment. I had a brief stint with Windows because I just can’t live without Morrowind/Oblivion. Whenever I find the time, I’ll be reinstalling Arch and enjoying my life again. My window manager of choice is fluxbox.
[/quote]
Oblivion works on Wine. I have not tested Morrowind but I think that will work to.[/quote]

bowserjr2, its too late for that…

Read full topic

item.title: Arch Linux Is Win
item.dc:creator: @mikkomainer Secet
item.description:
@mikkomainer wrote:

ThAt0n36Uy:

Start with Xubuntu before you move into a Distro like Arch. You might find the whole installation confusing if you’re not used to a non-graphical install.

I read the installing guide from ArchWiki and it didn’t look really difficult. Could I possible install it if I just follow the guide very carefully? Or are there things that they didn’t mention in the guide? Here is the guide: http://wiki.archlinux.org/index.php/Official_Arch_Linux_Install_Guide

And I see there is Ubuntu, Kubuntu, Xubunto. What’s the difference between those?

Read full topic

Silver Lining:

Uh, I don’t run Arch at the moment. I had a brief stint with Windows because I just can’t live without Morrowind/Oblivion. Whenever I find the time, I’ll be reinstalling Arch and enjoying my life again. My window manager of choice is fluxbox.

Oblivion works on Wine. I have not tested Morrowind but I think that will work to.

item.title: Arch Linux Is Win
item.dc:creator: @mikkomainer Secet
item.description:
@mikkomainer wrote:

I got Windows XP pro on my laptop. It has got AMD Turion X2 TL-58 1,9GHz, ATI mobility radeon HD 2400 XT, 2gb DDR2 and wlan.
Recently my XP has got really slow and it’s getting annoying. I was thinking reinstalling it, but then I started thinking: should I try Linux? I have never used Linux and don’t know really much about it.

Things that I want:
Minimalistic
Fast booting
Stable, good uptime

And if I have understood right, Linux has all that?

I can’t say I’m bad with computers, but I can’t also say I’m professional with them. Is it hard to get everything working in Arch? Are there good tutorials for first timers?

Read full topic

item.title: Arch Linux Is Win
item.dc:creator: @sdouble sdouble
item.description:
@sdouble wrote:

[quote=“Uriko, post:21, topic:191939”][quote author=solarwind link=topic=255620.msg2260654#msg2260654 date=1212635501]

I was gonna try it, but my friend told me I had to set up all the shit myself, etc… So I just installed Ubuntu… and wireless internet+ubuntu = hassle to do so I’m not using it right now lol

Arch Linux; Yes, you have to edit some configuration files manually…
[/quote]cbf do it for me[/quote]

Then linux is not for you. The beauty of Arch is the fact that it comes with only minimal utilities and just enough to get you by. It also has a large userbase, not quite as large as Ubuntu but just as helpful, and a wonderful wiki ( http://wiki.archlinux.org ). Soemtimes I find that the smaller userbase is better. There are less redundant and old solutions for the same problems that will no longer fix the issue you’re having.

You mentioned having a problem with Ubuntu + wireless. There is a wiki for ubuntu full of information as well. Arch’s solution: http://wiki.archlinux.org/index.php/Wireless Another nice thing about Arch is that it doesn’t come with a desktop environment. With Ubuntu, you’ll find many solutions when you look for help that require you to be using gnome. With Arch, you’ll find that most solutions do not care whether you’re using a desktop environment at all.

Read full topic

item.title: Arch Linux Is Win
item.dc:creator: @solarwind solarwind
item.description:
@solarwind wrote:

[quote=“Zach1188, post:16, topic:191939”][quote author=solarwind link=topic=255620.msg2242677#msg2242677 date=1211763937]

It is? Even though it’s not optimized by a USE flag?

I’m not going to argue with you. If you know so much, then you should know the answer to this simple question.
[/quote]
I’m not arguing, I don’t “know so much”. I was asking if it was still as fast, even though it’s not compiled for a specific USE flag, like Gentoo is.

“It is?” - Clearly, that’s a question, not an argument ;)[/quote]
Look, I’ve used both before. The difference is not noticeable. If you want “speed”, then you have to be prepared to edit configuration files. You can always rebuild your own vanilla kernel with all the flags you want, but I HIGHLY doubt you are better able to optimize a Linux kernel for i686 than the crew over there at Arch Linux. Your perception of speed comes from how snappy the system feels, in which case, you can improve it yourself. Just edit some configuration files, select what starts at boot-up, pick lightweight apps and build your system. Arch Linux is all about keeping it simple and building your system the way you want it. It’s easy to build a “slow” system by selecting a million daemons to boot up, picking the most heavy-weight software and so on… If you want speed, use things like fluxbox, or XFCE and things like that. Make use of Python, it’s fast. Ask on the Arch Linux forums; there’s a lot of knowledgeable people over there.

Read full topic

[/quote]
I’m not going to argue with you. If you know so much, then you should know the answer to this simple question.[/quote]
I’m not arguing, I don’t “know so much”. I was asking if it was still as fast, even though it’s not compiled for a specific USE flag, like Gentoo is.

“It is?” - Clearly, that’s a question, not an argument

item.title: Arch Linux Is Win
item.dc:creator: @solarwind solarwind
item.description:
@solarwind wrote:

Zach1188:

What are you on about? When you’re actually USING the OS, which is faster? I’m assuming you’ve used both, otherwise your arguments are theoretical.

I just answered your question. Using Arch Linux is JUST AS FAST AS GENTOO when you’re “actually USING the OS”. I have used BOTH and I know what I’m talking about.

Read full topic

item.title: Arch Linux Is Win
item.dc:creator: @solarwind solarwind
item.description:
@solarwind wrote:

[quote=“Zach1188, post:10, topic:191939”][quote author=solarwind link=topic=255620.msg2241420#msg2241420 date=1211702409]

How would you compare Arch linux to Gentoo? Is it any better?

Gentoo is a source distro. Compiling takes forever. Arch is a binary distro. It’s blazing fast.
[/quote]
Yes, compiling takes forever, but it’s very fast in runtime. How does Arch linux compare in terms of general use (not while compiling)?[/quote]
It’s not THAT much faster to compile, trust me. Arch Linux is VERY fast. Everything is i686 optimized.

Read full topic

item.description:
@ThAt0n36Uy wrote:

Silver Lining:

I actually do own a 360, and shelling out the cash for Oblivion is no problem for me. Thing is, you can’t get mods for Oblivion on the 360, and mods are an enormous (seriously, they make the game worth playing) part of the game.

They have the mods in the Xbox Live MarketPlace I believe.

Read full topic
